Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of bearded male figure to right (part of head with hair and beard in added red, shoulder, and himation remain); at right, part of oblique line, perhaps head of spear.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Perhaps seated Priam being threatened by Neoptolemos.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 127, pl. XXXVIII, no. 353.4)
CVA Boston I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum, USA Fasc. 14, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Fasc. 1 (p.44, pl. 58, no.5)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 232, no. 181)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0852)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4760 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
